caption.title: List of the different methods used to infer dominance rank from dyadic interactions in published studies that tested the relationship between dominance rank and bib size in male house sparrows (N = 13 published studies, 11 different methods).
caption.p: Note that some studies used more than one method to estimate dominance rank and that unpublished studies are not included in this summary.

fn.p: *Order of preference used for the analyses (see main text). The order of preference was determined based on both how frequently the method was used in previous studies and by taking into account the (expected) performance of each of the methods. First, higher order of preference was assigned to methods specifically designed for inferring linear dominance hierarchies (i.e. David’s score, I and SI, Landau’s and Kendall’s linearity indices). We used the information available in Sánchez-Tójar et al., 2018b to rank David’s score and I and SI as first and second methods in preference, respectively. Second, we ranked the remaining (proportion-based) methods based on how frequently they were used in previous studies. Importantly, the order of preference was chosen prior to conducting any statistical analysis, and thus, method selection was blind to the outcome of the analyses.
